citation.article-title: Serinibacter salmoneus gen. nov., sp. nov., an actinobacterium isolated from the intestinal tract of a fish, and emended descriptions of the families Beutenbergiaceae and Bogoriellaceae
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Serinibacter (Se.ri′ni.bac.ter. N.L. n. serinum serine; N.L. masc. n. bacter rod; N.L. masc. n. Serinibacter a rod with serine in the cell wall).
Cells are irregular, rod-shaped, Gram-positive and non-sporulating.
Growth occurs under both aerobic and anaerobic conditions.
The cell-wall peptidoglycan is of the A4α type with an l-Ser residue at position 1 of the peptide subunit.
The menaquinone is MK-8(H4), and the major polar lipids are phosphatidylethanolamine and phosphatidylglycerol.
The fatty acid profile consists of iso- and anteiso- branched and straight-chain fatty acids.
The major cell-wall sugar is galactose.
Mycolic acids are absent, and the acyl type of muramic acid is N-acetyl.
Phylogenetically, the genus Serinibacter belongs to the family Beutenbergiaceae within the suborder Micrococcineae.
The type species is Serinibacter salmoneus.
